Award.AwardTitle: Microbes, Diet, and Hominin Evolution: Comparative and Metagenomic Approaches

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will explore microbial communities residing in human and nonhuman primate gastrointestinal tracts in order to understand the roles microbes have played in the evolution of humans, human ancestors, and related species. This project represents the first large-scale comparative research project centered on the roles of microbes in human evolution. With data collected as part of this project, the researchers will be able to assess whether changes in microbial communities influenced human evolution or whether humans evolved largely independently of microbial metabolism, where cultural or other innovations have played a larger role.

The research will use two complementary data sets to investigate the significance of microbiomes in human and nonhuman primate diets. First, the taxonomic composition of microbes residing in twenty-four nonhuman primate species, including humans, will be described. Second, the metabolic processes undertaken by microbes in ten primate species, including humans, will be analyzed. These lines of evidence will be evaluated in light of dietary information for each species, with all major primate dietary categories represented. A broad taxonomic range of primates will be analyzed, and information about dietary changes during human evolution will be utilized. The genetic analyses of microbial samples will involve advanced and emerging sequencing and metagenomic techniques focused on two types of microbe: bacteria and archaea, a group of single-celled microorganisms that were once grouped with bacteria, but are now considered to be an evolutionarily distinct group.

The main intellectual contribution of this study will be to understand the evolutionary dynamics of primate hosts and commensal microbes, particularly to determine if microbes provide benefits that hosts could not have evolved on their own.

With respect to broader impacts, this research will establish an evolutionary baseline for assessing human microbial diseases. This will complement ongoing research through the Human Microbiome Project. The findings are expected to provide insights into a wide range of human gastrointestinal diseases. In addition, the project will train and develop the research capabilities of students and researchers, including those from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Microbes, Diet, and Hominin Evolution: Comparative and Metagenomic Approaches

The major goal of this project is to evaluate how primate gastrointestinal microorganisms contribute to digestive function and health, and in turn how communities of these microorganisms have impacted  the course of primate and human evolution.

Microbes generate energy surpluses and impact primate energy balances which has profound implications for understanding primate (including human) evolution and health. The study?s intellectual contribution is to understand the evolutionary dynamics of primate hosts and microbes, particularly to determine if microbes provide benefits that hosts could not have evolved on their own. With the help of NSF funding, we have made pioneering and significant contributions to the understanding of primate gut microbial diversity. Research activities for this project focused on collecting an invaluable set of wild and captive fecal samples and rectal swabs from a diversity of primate taxa, extracting and sequencing microbial 16S rDNA data from the samples, and then analyzing these microbial species abundance and diversity among hosts.  We test hypotheses that may explain GI microbial community differences through (i) phylogeny (ii) encephalization, (iii) ecology and other relevant factors. Over the course of this project, we have sequenced over 6,000 samples from 34 primate species across a very broad taxonomic range. An additional aspect of the project investigates the function of microbial genes harbored by bacteria. Along with several diverse collaborators, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students, we have made great strides in assessing factors impacting primate gut microbiomes, assessing interactions between gut microbiomes, energy provision and health, and creating and applying new algorithms for phylogenetic analyses of microbiomes.

Co-PIs, collaborators, students and post-docs have shared our results from this NSF-funded research at over 30 conferences and in more than 20 publications with more forthcoming.

The intellectual merits of this project include:  The analyses of gut microbiomes from over 30 primate species to provide the first comprehensive evolutionary study of primate gut microbial communities and their genomes (microbiomes). We defined and compared microbial communities for thousands of primate samples and quantified metabolic processes in a subset of these species. These analyses examine and test factors affecting microbiome community composition and function and have provided and continue to provide groundbreaking insight into the determinants of microbial community composition at various comparative levels including within and among hosts, social groups, habitats, host species, and over time. The diverse sample collection continues to provide fodder for additional studies and insights into host-microbial relationships and interactions.

Broader Impacts: Our research has valuable implications for evolutionary biology, biomedicine and conservation. For example, gut microbiome imbalances can lead to morbidity and mortality in both human and non-human primates. Our work may lead to development of nonhuman primate models of human gastrointestinal diseases. Understanding primate host-microbe interactions will enhance disease recognition and treatment. In addition, we are dedicated to increasing opportunities for underrepresented students in the sciences. We have provided lab and field research experiences and our team has helped to bridge academia and industry with myriad opportunities for diverse and underrepresented students and students, staff, and postdocs. This work has been disseminated widely in publications and conference presentations, including symposia and courses, including online. Novel DNA sequences have been deposited in GENBANK. We will continue to use this emerging research and invaluable diverse dataset in undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral training and anticipate continued cross-disciplinary and collaborative research and teaching, combining anthropologists, computer scientists, and microbiologists to examine issues in primate and human evolution and evolutionary medicine.
